Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Synthesizing volcanic music: Comparing natural and synthetic signals to constrain the physics

POR.DRECONTENT:
Harmonic tremor is one of the most beautiful and frequently recorded signals recorded at active volcanoes worldwide.  In many ways, it can be considered the music or the song of the volcano, although the volcanoes ‘sing’ at a frequency below what the human ear can hear. Fortunately, the advance in monitoring of active volcanoes using seismometers and low frequency microphones has allowed us to record these signals from many volcanoes, which has led to a number of theoretical models as to how harmonic tremor is generated. What we have observed in our work at several different active volcanoes is that there are periods of activity that generate harmonic tremor that are only recorded on seismometers, while other times the signal is recorded on seismometers and low frequency microphones. In other words, sometimes the signal is only produced in the interior of the volcano, but other times the signal produced within the volcano is also transmitted into the atmosphere. The purpose of our experiment was to try to understand what controls whether the signals produced in the volcano are also emitted into the atmosphere. 

My Japanese research hosts and I thought that it would be interesting to try a fresh approach to this problem, so we developed and built an experimental apparatus to physically generate signals very similar to those generated by the volcano in the laboratory. The experimental setup consisted of generating a regular signal and harmonic oscillation with compressed air, a flapping membrane, and an elastic chamber. This signal was passed through a tank containing a gel that represented the physical analogue to magma within the volcanic conduit. Although the gel was at room temperature and magma is typically around 1000 °C, the gel and the magma behave physically very similarly.  Thus, we had an experimental system where the analogue of volcanic gases were flowing through the analogue of magma and then ‘erupting’ or degassing into the atmosphere. We placed pressure sensors within the portion of the experiment isolated from the atmosphere (the analogue volcanic ‘conduit’), as well as microphones around the tank containing the gel. High-speed video and normal digital video of each experiment were recorded to observe the ‘eruptions’ within the tank containing the gel.

Because this was a short (10 week) summer experiment, we focused on varying just one experimental parameter, the viscosity of the gel. This represented changing magma viscosity at the volcano, which has been widely observed. The results of the experiment showed that when the viscosity of the gel was low, the gas pumped into the gel produced bubbles that rose to the surface and popped. The popping was the primary signal observed in the atmosphere, even though the pressure sensors isolated from the atmosphere recorded clear harmonic signals. We related this to a period of volcanic activity at Fuego volcano, Guatemala in which frequent bubble-bursting-type explosions were recorded in the microphones and the seismometers. During this activity, harmonic tremor was only clearly recorded in the seismic data. 

Alternatively, when the gel viscosity was high, the compressed gas formed open, stable pathways in the gel. When the pathways were open, the harmonic signals recorded within the ‘conduit’ were also clearly recorded in the atmosphere with the microphones. We related these results to a period of activity recorded from Fuego volcano in 2009, when the explosions were much stronger than in 2008 and harmonic tremor was clearly recorded in both the seismometers and the low frequency microphones.
